title: German submarine U-358
text:
German submarine "U-358" was a <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">Type VIIC</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> of <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>'s "<a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a>" during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
She carried out five patrols before being sunk north of the <a href="Azores">Azores</a> by British warships on 1 March 1944.
She sank four ships and one warship.
Design.
<a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">German Type VIIC submarines</a> were preceded by the shorter <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIB">Type VIIB submarines</a>. "U-358" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. She had a total length of , a <a href="pressure%20hull">pressure hull</a> length of , a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of , a height of , and a <a href="draught%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The submarine was powered by two <a href="Germaniawerft">Germaniawerft</a> F46 four-stroke, six-cylinder <a href="supercharged">supercharged</a> <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s producing a total of for use while surfaced, two <a href="AEG">AEG</a> GU 460/8–27 <a href="Motor%E2%80%93generator">double-acting electric motors</a> producing a total of for use while submerged. She had two shafts and two <a href="propeller">propeller</a>s. The boat was capable of operating at depths of up to .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of . When submerged, the boat could operate for at ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "U-358" was fitted with five <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s (four fitted at the bow and one at the stern), fourteen <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es, one <a href="8.8%20cm%20SK%20C/35%20naval%20gun">SK C/35 naval gun</a>, 220 rounds, and two twin <a href="2%20cm%20FlaK%2030">C/30</a> <a href="anti-aircraft%20gun">anti-aircraft gun</a>s. The boat had a <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> of between forty-four and sixty.
Service history.
The submarine was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 25 June 1940 at the <a href="Flensburger%20Schiffbau-Gesellschaft">Flensburger Schiffbau-Gesellschaft</a> yard at <a href="Flensburg">Flensburg</a> as yard number 477, <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> on 30 April 1942 and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 15 August under the command of "<a href="Oberleutnant%20zur%20See">Oberleutnant zur See</a>" Rolf Manke.
First patrol.
The boat's first patrol was in two parts; it began with her departure from <a href="Kiel">Kiel</a> on 12 January 1943. During the second part, which began with her departure from <a href="Kristiansand">Kristiansand</a> in Norway on the 16th, she negotiated the <a href="GIUK%20gap">gap</a> between <a href="Iceland">Iceland</a> and the <a href="Faroe%20Islands">Faroe Islands</a> and sank the "Neva" west of these islands on the 22nd. On the 26th, she sank the "Nortind" east of <a href="Cape%20Farewell%2C%20Greenland">Cape Farewell</a>, (<a href="Greenland">Greenland</a>). She arrived at <a href="St.%20Nazaire">St. Nazaire</a> in occupied France on 8 March.
Second patrol.
Having left St. Nazaire (which would be her base for the rest of her career) on 11 April 1943, "U-357" sank the "Bristol City" and the "Wentworth"; she was attacked south of Cape Farewell by the British corvette commanded by Lieutenant Robert Atkinson and badly damaged. (This attack had originally credited "Pink" with the destruction of .)
Third patrol.
The submarine's third foray took her south, as far as the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Guinea">Gulf of Guinea</a>, off the west African coast. At 84 days, it was her longest patrol.
Fourth patrol.
Sortie number four saw the boat northeast of the Azores.
Fifth patrol and loss.
"U-357" had left St. Nazaire on 14 February 1944. From the 29th, she was hunted by the British frigates , , and north of the Azores. "Gore" and "Garlies" had to break off the assault and sail to <a href="Gibraltar">Gibraltar</a> to re-fuel. The U-boat sank "Gould" on 1 March, but "Affleck" persisted with the attack, sinking "U-358" with gunfire after the submarine was forced to the surface.
50 men died in the U-boat; there was one survivor, Alfons Eckert.
